lines.text: Today we started the kit. The only part to build is the cartridge amplifier, which is tube based.

lines.text: It is wise to start with low components first, and then go up in height. Thus, we have the following (partial) order:

lines.text: R1, R3, R4, and R7. It's a little hard to read the color code on the redish background, so I recommend confirming every value with a multimeter
lines.text_raw: R1, R3, R4, and R7. It's a little hard to read the color code on the redish background, so I recommend confirming every value with a multimeter

lines.text: C7, C9, and C10. All are .1 uF and are labeled 104. Similar to the resistor color code, the first digit in the label is 1, so the first digit in the value is 1; the second digit is zero; and the third digit (4) tells how many zeros follow so we have 100000. This is in pF, so divide by 1000 to get 100 nF, and then by 1000 again to get .1 uF

lines.text: R6, R10, and C4. Notes: (1) both leads must fit through the metal ring in the ceramic insulator. It's tight, but it can fit. Easier to insert the thinner wire first (C4) and then the thicker wire is stronger to push through Note 2: Don't trim the leads flush, as ou will need to solder wires onto both of them later
